snippet.title: This is the famed Russian tank corps that Putin is sending to NATO's borders
snippet.content:
As many as 100,000 Russian troops will be in Belarus in September for the Zapad military exercises, and with them will be a storied tank corps.
The 1st Guards Tank Army, a historic that President Vladimir Putin re-assembled in 2015, is being sent to take part in the Zapad military exercise, which means "west" in Russian.
A number of western generals and politicians have expressed about the Zapad military exercise in the last few months.
"People are worried this is a Trojan horse," US Army Gen. Ben Hodges Reuters in July. "They say, 'We're just doing an exercise,' and then all of a sudden they have moved all these people and capabilities somewhere."
"For Russian troops going to Belarus, it is a one-way ticket," Estonia's Defence Minister Margus Tsahkna Reuters in April.
Coincidentally or not, the 1st Guards Tank Army was re-assembled "to neutralise the threat from the Baltic countries," to Zvezda, a Russian Defence Ministry news outlet.
Formed in 1943, the Russian tank army made hell for the Nazis in World War II.
The "1st Guards Tank Army was arguably the most famous of the six tank armies the Soviets formed during the Soviet-German War," historian David Glantz .
The tank army was instrumental in the battle of Kursk, in fighting in Ukraine, as well as in the Soviet Union's advance into Poland and eventually Berlin, Glantz said.
In 1944, it raced through Ukraine and surrounded the Nazi's 1st Panzer Division for which it was given its "Guards" designation, Glantz said. The tank army then led the advance to Berlin where it surrounded the city.
The tank army was also in the quelling of the 1968 Prague Spring. "The Russians understand its significance, and so do the Belorussians and Ukrainians," Glantz said.
The tank army is by Maj. Gen. Alexander Chaiko, and consists of soldiers, , 600 to 800 infantry , and 300 to 400 units.
More specifically, the tank army will be with T-72B3 and T-80 tanks, BPM-2 combat vehicles and 130 other kinds of combat equipment.
BPM-2s are light-armoured amphibious vehicles that sport a 30mm automatic canon. Both the have 9M119 Refleks anti-tank guided missile systems that fire from their 125mm canons. But the former is certainly the main tank in Russia's arsenal, as they have about 1,900 in service and 7,000 in reserve.
The tank army is also slated to be the first unit to the advanced tank, but due to budget problems, it still has not been put into mass production.
Despite the tank army's storied past, that it was intended to NATO in a possible Third World War, and that it's being sent to NATO's borders only two years after being re-assembled, Russia has made statements about how its to be used.
Russian military expert Victor Murakhovsky has that the tank army is only intended to be stationed in Moscow, while Russian Gen. Eugene Buzhinsky has "if earlier, [Russia] had very moderate groups [military formations] oriented toward the Western direction, now they will be significantly strengthened."
Whatever the case, Baltic States have cause for concern, as many have been repeatedly victimized by Russia's hybrid warfare, which some is the main reason the 1st Guards Tank Army was re-assembled in the first place.
